results.snippet: Throughout their lives, MARK and SCOTT KELLY have followed more or less the same path. On Wednesday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced that they were the first set of twins selected as astronauts, The Associated Press...
results.lead_paragraph: Throughout their lives, MARK and SCOTT KELLY have followed more or less the same path. On Wednesday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced that they were the first set of twins selected as astronauts, The Associated Press reported. . The twins, 32, are both Navy lieutenants and fighter pilots at the Naval Air Station at Patuxent River, Md. More than 2,400 people applied for the astronaut class of 1996, and 35 were selected. Ten of them, including the Kelly twins, were chosen to be shuttle pilot candidates. The rest will be mission specialists.

headline.main: Texas-Theme Story Readings Bring Delight to Dallas

results.snippet: On the first night of the new literary season, the actor Barry Corbin brought the house down, Texas style.         He was reading "Sick Day," a short story by Tom Doyal about a middle-aged bookkeeper's day off, to a packed auditorium at the Dallas...
results.lead_paragraph: On the first night of the new literary season, the actor Barry Corbin brought the house down, Texas style. He was reading "Sick Day," a short story by Tom Doyal about a middle-aged bookkeeper's day off, to a packed auditorium at the Dallas Museum of Art, and he could barely get through a line without hysterical laughter from the audience.

results.snippet: CONNECTICUT is looking for your vacation dollars . . . and, for that matter,  those of everyone else within reasonable driving distance.         It's obvious in the message of the brochures at the Welcome Centers in major  highway rest stops. And...
results.lead_paragraph: CONNECTICUT is looking for your vacation dollars . . . and, for that matter, those of everyone else within reasonable driving distance. It's obvious in the message of the brochures at the Welcome Centers in major highway rest stops. And it'll be even clearer as the state starts hawking its attributes on television, in publications and in several railroad stations -- pointing to beautiful natural scenery, rustic inns and cultural attractions .

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour, beginning a 10-day mission to explore new technologies, on Monday was to deploy and test a large antenna that inflates like a balloon to tennis-court size.         The experiment, a highlight of the mission, which began...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour, beginning a 10-day mission to explore new technologies, on Monday was to deploy and test a large antenna that inflates like a balloon to tennis-court size. The experiment, a highlight of the mission, which began today with a problem-free launching, could be the prelude to constructing large, inflatable structures in space that cost significantly less than a comparable solid counterpart, say engineers of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

results.snippet: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour watched today as an inflatable antenna was unfurled from a satellite as part of a NASA experiment to find cheaper ways to build orbiting structures.         The prototype antenna was sprung from a...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour watched today as an inflatable antenna was unfurled from a satellite as part of a NASA experiment to find cheaper ways to build orbiting structures. The prototype antenna was sprung from a small satellite released by the shuttle, which hovered 400 feet away and transmitted live television pictures of the event.

headline.main: Shuttle Retrieves a Satellite With Experiments

results.snippet: A 50-foot robot arm on the space shuttle Endeavour reached out today and plucked from orbit a small satellite carrying the results of a test of cheaper space structures.         A Canadian astronaut, Marc Garneau, maneuvered the shuttle's...
results.lead_paragraph: A 50-foot robot arm on the space shuttle Endeavour reached out today and plucked from orbit a small satellite carrying the results of a test of cheaper space structures. A Canadian astronaut, Marc Garneau, maneuvered the shuttle's Canadian-built robot arm to grab the glistening, gold-colored Spartan satellite.

headline.main: How To Get To Mars (And Make Millions!)

results.snippet: The urge to venture afar] arises from the threefold nature of man. One motive is fame, for it is the nature of man to journey where there is great danger, and thus win honor and praise. A second motive is curiosity, for it is also man's nature to see...
results.lead_paragraph: The urge to venture afar] arises from the threefold nature of man. One motive is fame, for it is the nature of man to journey where there is great danger, and thus win honor and praise. A second motive is curiosity, for it is also man's nature to see the things he has heard about, and thus learn whether they are as he has been told or not. The third is the desire for gain, for men seek wealth wherever they have heard that gain is to be gotten. -- FROM "THE KING'S MIRROR," A 13TH-CENTURY NORSE TREATISE WHEN HUMANS FINALLY ACQUIRED the technology to travel to another planet, it occurred to them that they didn't really want to go. A manned mission to Mars, the fantasy that had paid the mortgage for generations of science-fiction writers, lost its appeal as soon as NASA plotted the itinerary. The $400 billion price tag seemed absurdly high to a nation bored with the sight of astronauts lumbering around craters. We already had enough extraterrestrial rocks, thank you. Recently, though, an intriguing modification to NASA's Mars plan has been suggested: ditch NASA. Let private explorers, modern Vikings inspired by the Norsemen's third desire, seek wealth on Mars. The basics of the expedition have been worked out by Robert M. Zubrin, who has his own research and development company, Pioneer Astronautics, in Denver. Since devising the technology for a simple and cheap mission to Mars, Zubrin has been traveling the globe giving passionate lectures about "our generation's New World." He tells audiences of the prizes offered by 15th-century Portuguese and Spanish rulers to entrepreneurs for venturing down the African coast and across the Atlantic. (Columbus's expedition was financed not only by Queen Isabella but also by private merchants who stood to gain trading concessions.) Zubrin thinks that if the United States Government were to offer a Mars Prize of $20 billion -- four times what he estimates a private mission would cost -- entrepreneurs would take the bait. If they made it to Mars and back, pocketing the prize, they could turn a nice profit; if they failed, taxpayers wouldn't be stuck with the bill.

headline.main: In Season of Commencements, Words of Wisdom Heard Anew

results.snippet: Yogi Berra, the former Yankee great, might describe this year's commencement  speeches (and his own at Montclair State University in New Jersey) as deja vu all over again. Few speakers focused on major news events or looked ahead to the Presidential...
results.lead_paragraph: Yogi Berra, the former Yankee great, might describe this year's commencement speeches (and his own at Montclair State University in New Jersey) as deja vu all over again. Few speakers focused on major news events or looked ahead to the Presidential election. Most recycled popular themes: unity, family, public service. Among the speakers: a frog named Kermit. These excerpts were taken from transcripts provided by universities and colleges.

headline.main: Satellite Orients Itself, Shuttle Astronauts Find

results.snippet: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour crept up on a small self-orienting satellite for a final check today, taking precise laser measurements before abandoning the craft to burn up in Earth's atmosphere.         The shuttle's third rendezvous...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour crept up on a small self-orienting satellite for a final check today, taking precise laser measurements before abandoning the craft to burn up in Earth's atmosphere. The shuttle's third rendezvous with the 80-pound aluminum cylinder was a relief for scientists who were nearly forced to evaluate their experiment solely through radar data and video recorded by astronauts.

headline.main: Shuttle Lands in Florida After 10-Day Mission

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a landing here today after a 10-day mission in which its crew of six astronauts tested an inflatable antenna and a self-stabilizing satellite.         The shuttle landed at the Kennedy Space Center at 7:09 A.M.,...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a landing here today after a 10-day mission in which its crew of six astronauts tested an inflatable antenna and a self-stabilizing satellite. The shuttle landed at the Kennedy Space Center at 7:09 A.M., ending a 4.1-million-mile voyage that began on May 19.
